title: Stadia won’t support mobile networks, wireless joypad isn’t wireless
text:
Stadia at launch is going to be a bit of a compromise

Wi-Fi will be the only way to use Stadia at launch and unless you have a Chromecast Ultra for your TV the controller won’t be wireless.

The more small print that gets revealed for Google Stadia the more it seems like it’s being rushed out before it’s ready, as more limitations are announced for the service at launch.

The first is that the Stadia’s wireless controller is only actually wireless when used via a Chromecast Ultra dongle for your TV. For anything else you’ll have to plug it in using a USB-C cable.

So, if you intend to use Stadia via a PC or phone or tablet then you’ll have to have it plugged it.

That may not seem like much of a hardship but it does negate what was meant to be a key feature of Stadia, in that you can seamlessly move from one device to another, playing the same game and not even needing to recalibrate the controller.

It was an important enough feature that Google demonstrated it live on stage during Stadia’s unveiling but now apparently it won’t be working until sometime after launch.

Another problem is that all of a sudden Google are saying that to use Stadia you will need a proper Wi-Fi connection and that it won’t work on a standard mobile network.

This only emerged during a podcast from The Verge, during which Google announced that their Pixel 2 and Pixel 2 XL phones will also work with Stadia, as well as the previously announced Pixel 3, Pixel 3a, and Pixel 4.

‘It’s just going to run on Wi-Fi to start’, said Google’s Rick Osterloh. Which obviously immediately limits how portable the service actually is.

Previously, only a ‘reliable Internet connection’ was specified as a requirement, implying a good mobile data connection would’ve been fine.

All of which, purposefully or not, makes using Stadia via your TV by far the preferable option at launch.

Google are promising that the missing features will be fully implemented after launch but they’re clearly in a rush to make sure that Microsoft does not steal their thunder with Project xCloud.

Although xCloud doesn’t have a confirmed date for its full release invites to public previews started going out this week (so we should have a report on it shortly).

Advertisement

Advertisement

Project xCloud does support mobile connections and wireless controllers and yet you don’t have to pay anything for the preview service. Stadia though is £8.99 a month and only those who pay £119 for the Founder’s Pack will be able to use it when it launches on 19 November.

Google clearly don’t want to be late to the streaming party but Stadia at launch sounds like it’s only going to be a shadow of what’s planned for next year and beyond.
